[[Sera Monastery]] |occupation = |teacher = |reincarnation of = |predecessor = |successor = |students = |spouse = |partner = [[Christie McNally]] (2003-2009) |children = |website = [http://aciphx.org/ aciphx.org] }} '''Michael Roach''' (born 1952) is an American non-traditional teacher of [[Tibetan Buddhism]]. Ordained as a [[Gelugpa]] monk, he was the first American to receive the [[Geshe]] degree at [[Sera Monastery]] in [[India]].{{cite book| last =Seager| first =Richard Hughes| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =Buddhism in America| publisher =[[Columbia University Press]]| year =2000| location =| pages = 122, 160| url =| doi =| id = | isbn = 0-231-10868-0}} He has started a number of businesses and organizations, written books about Buddhism, and translated Tibetan Buddhist teachings. Roach has written and lectured that yoga, meditation, and a practice of helping others—even competitors—leads to financial prosperity.Guy Adams, [http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/the-death-of-yoga-student-ian-thorson---and-the-wall-of-meditative-silence-that-met-police-7821159.html "The death of yoga student Ian Thorson – and the 'wall of meditative silence' that met police"], ''The Independent'', 7 June 2012 He has at times been the center of controversy for his views, teachings, activities, and behavior.http://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/06/us/mysterious-yoga-retreat-ends-in-a-grisly-death.html?pagewanted=all[http://abcnews.go.com/US/buddhist-yoga-retreat-death-raises-questions-ariz-monks/story?id=16526754&page=2#.T9vDcb_22bQ Page 2: Buddhist Yoga Retreat Death Raises Questions on Ariz. Monk's 'Enlightenment' Preaching - ABC News][http://www.slate.com/articles/life/family/2008/06/on_a_short_leash.html Buddhist partnership ends in divorce, remarriage, and now death: What happens when a couple never strays more than 15 feet from each other? - Slate Magazine][http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/the-death-of-yoga-student-ian-thorson---and-the-wall-of-meditative-silence-that-met-police-7821159.html The death of yoga student Ian Thorson – and the 'wall of meditative silence' that met police - Americas - World - The Independent] ==Biography== Michael Roach was born in [[Los Angeles, California]] in 1952 to [[Episcopal Church in the United States of America|Episcopalian]] parents, and grew up in [[Phoenix, Arizona]]. After his high school graduation, he received the [[Presidential Scholars Program|Presidential Scholars Medallion]] from U.S. President [[Richard Nixon]], then attended [[Princeton University]] in 1972. He traveled to India in 1973 to seek Buddhist instruction, while still in college. He returned to the United States and received a scholarship to return to study in India in 1974. While in India, Roach learned about a Tibetan Buddhist monastery in [[New Jersey]] led by a Mongolian-born lama, [[Sermey Khensur Lobsang Tharchin]]. Roach returned to Princeton, living at the monastery from 1975 to 1981.[http://www.elephantjournal.com/2012/06/essays-to-answer-questions-from-my-friends-geshe-michael-roach/ Essays to Answer Questions from my Friends. ~ Geshe Michael Roach | elephant journal] In the year before his graduation in 1975, both of his parents died due to cancer and then his brother committed suicide.{{cite book| last =Paine| first =Jeffrey| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =Adventures With The Buddha| publisher =[[W. W. Norton & Company]]| year =2005| location =| pages = 369–373| url =| doi =| id = | isbn = 0-393-05906-5}} In 1983 he was ordained as a [[Gelugpa]] [[Buddhist monk]] at [[Sera Monastery]] in South India, where he would periodically travel and study.{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =Geshe Michael Roach| work =| publisher =Diamond Mountain| date =| url =http://www.diamondmountain.org/about/lineage_and_roots| format =| doi =| accessdate = 2012-06-09}} In 1995, he became the first American to qualify for the [[Geshe]] degree.{{cite book |last=Seager |middle=Hughes |first=Richard |title=Buddhism in America |publisher=[[Columbia University Press]] |year=1999 |isbn=0-231-10869-9 |pages=259–260}} Beginning in 1981, Roach helped found and run Andin International, a jewelry manufacturer based in New York. He used proceeds from his work to set up [[financial endowment]]s to fund various projects, in particular the Sera Mey Food Fund. Roach used these experiences as the basis for a book, ''The Diamond Cutter'', in which he explains how to apply the lessons of the [[Diamond Sutra|Diamond Cutter Sutra]] in the context of business.{{cite web |url=http://articles.businessinsider.com/2011-06-18/strategy/30091918_1_diamond-cutter-buddha-book-worthwhile |publisher=[[Business Insider]] |month=June |year=2011 |title=Kindle Book Review: The Diamond Cutter: The Buddha on Managing Your Business and Your Life |accessdate=2012-07-12}} In 1987, Roach founded the Asian Classics Input Project (ACIP). He founded ACIP with the goal of producing a complete and electronically searchable version of the [[Kangyur]] and [[Tengyur]], together with related philosophical commentaries and dictionaries.{{cite book |last=Seager |middle=Hughes |first=Richard |title=Buddhism in America |publisher=[[Columbia University Press]] |year=1999 |isbn=0-231-10869-9 |pages=122–123}} ACIP has input over 8,500 texts—nearly half a million pages—which it has made available for free. ACIP also provides a means of earning income for many Tibetan refugees.{{cite web|last=|first=|month=|year=|title=Overview—Asian Classics Input Project|url=http://www.asianclassics.org/about/overview|format=|doi=|accessdate=2011-06-02}} From 1993 to 1999, Roach developed and taught 18 courses on Tibetan Buddhism in New York City. These courses were based on the training monks receive in Tibetan monasteries, but organized to be taught in a conventional western setting.{{cite web|last=|first=|authorlink=|title=The Principal Teachings of Buddhism|work=|month=|year=1993|url=http://www.theknowledgebase.com/browse/products.php?product=ACI-Course-01%3A-The-Principal-Teachings-of-Buddhism-%281993%2C-New-York%2C-Geshe-Michael-Roach%29|format=|doi=|accessdate=2011-06-02}}{{cite web|last=|first=|authorlink=|title=The Great Ideas of Buddhism, Part 3|work=|month=|year=1999|url=http://www.theknowledgebase.com/browse/products.php?product=ACI-Course-18%3A-The-Great-Ideas-of-Buddhism%2C-Part-3-%281999%2C-New-York%2C-Geshe-Michael-Roach%29|format=|doi=|accessdate=2011-06-02}}{{cite web |title=Asian Classics Institute |url=http://www.acidharma.org/aci/index.html |accessdate=June 22, 2012}} From 2000 to 2003, Roach organized and led a three-year silent retreat in the [[Arizona]] desert with five other participants, modified from Tibetan traditions.{{cite web| last =Furber| first =Matt| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =Yoga and meditation mix to improve business acumen| work =| publisher =Idaho Mountain Express| date =2004-04-09| url =http://www.mtexpress.com/2004/04-04-09/04-04-09monk.htm| doi =| accessdate = 2008-01-02}}{{cite book| last =Wilson| first =Jeff| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =The Buddhist Guide to New York| publisher =[[St. Martin's Press]]| year =2000| location =| url =| doi =| id = | isbn = 0-312-26715-0| page = 85}} In 2004, Roach established [[Diamond Mountain Center]], a Buddhist retreat center and seminary in Arizona. ===Marriage and controversy=== {{criticism-section|date=July 2012}} [[File:Allegra greeting Geshe Michael and Lama Christie.jpg|thumb|right|Geshe Michael Roach and Christie McNally]] In 1996, Christie McNally, then a recent college graduate, became Roach's student. They began a "spiritual partnership" in which they took vows that included never being more than 15 feet apart, eating from the same plate, reading the same books together, etc. They were secretly married in a [[Christian]] ceremony in [[Rhode Island]] in 1998 and kept their relationship secret until 2003. When news of the marriage emerged, Roach explained to the ''New York Times'' that they had wished to honor their Christian heritage and that he wanted McNally to be entitled to his possessions if something happened to him.Fernanda Santos, [http://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/06/us/mysterious-yoga-retreat-ends-in-a-grisly-death.html "Mysterious Yoga Retreat in the Desert Ends in a Grisly Death"], ''New York Times'', 6 June 2012. In a 1996 Asiaweek cover story the [[Dalai Lama]] commented; "- a monk with a wife. This is wrong. A monk is celibate. Those who dress like a monk, with a wife, they are not monks. Of course, it's the individual's right. You can always give up a monk's vows, and then change your dress."{{cite news |url=http://www-cgi.cnn.com/ASIANOW/asiaweek/96/0510/feat1.html |title=The Private Dalai Lama |accessdate=2012-07-26 |author=Ron Gluckman |date=May 10, 1996 |publisher=Asiaweek}} The controversy centers around a Buddhist practice in which two practitioners use sexual intercourse as a means of strongly focusing the consciousness in order to strengthen the realization of emptiness. According to the Dalai Lama, "Yogis who have achieved a high level of the path and are fully qualified can engage in sexual activity, and a monastic with this ability can maintain all the precepts...Such a practitioner can make spiritual use not only of delicious meat and drink, but even of human excrement and urine. A yogi’s meditation transforms these into real ambrosia. For people like us, however, this is beyond our reach. As long as you cannot transform piss and shit, these other things should not be done!"{{cite book |title=How To Practice |author=His Holiness the Dalai Lama |coauthor=Jeffrey Hopkins, PhD. |publisher=[[Simon & Schuster]] |year=2002 |ISBN=0-7434-2708-4 |page=193}} [[Robert Thurman]], a former monk and fellow Buddhist scholar, expressed skepticism that Roach was at such a level of practice, referring to it as "superhuman". Some Buddhist leaders, including Thurman, urged him to renounce his monastic vows and stop wearing his robes; Roach did not comply.{{cite news |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/05/15/garden/15buddhists.html?pagewanted=1&ei=5087&em&en=729a029c0a34c0e5&ex=1211083200 |title=Making Their Own Limits in a Spiritual Partnership |accessdate=2008-05-29 |author=Leslie Kaufman |date=May 15, 2008 |publisher=The New York Times}} In addition, Roach's practice of appearing in public with McNally raised concerns. When Roach proposed to teach in [[Dharamsala, Himachal Pradesh|Dharamshala]] in 2006, the Office of the Dalai Lama rebuffed his plan, stating that Roach's "unconventional behavior does not accord with His Holiness’s teachings and practices"; the teaching took place in nearby [[Palampur]] instead. McNally left Roach in the middle of 2009"{{cite web |url=http://www.nypost.com/pagesixmag/issues/20100211/Monk+y+Business+Controversial+NYC+guru+Michael+Roach |title=Monk-y Business: Controversial NYC guru Michael Roach |accessdate=2010-06-24 |author=Beth Landman |date=Feb 11, 2010 |publisher=Page Six Magazine}} and Roach filed for divorce in September 2010. {{off-topic|date=July 2012}} ===Student's death=== McNally married one of Roach's students, Ian Thorson, on October 3, 2010. McNally entered a three-year retreat with Thorson at the Diamond Mountain Center in December 2010. Roach published an open letter stating that McNally admitted in February 2012 to a violation of the terms under which students are allowed to reside at the center, and the Diamond Mountain board of directors asked McNally and Thorson to leave the retreat. Thorson and McNally left the Diamond Mountain property, but secretly set up camp in a cave on [[Bureau of Land Management]] land nearby, within the retreat boundaries. Thorson died in April 2012 of dehydration and exposure.[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2155340/Diamond-Mountain-retreat-death-Ian-Thorson-dies-fleeing-mysterious-yoga-retreat-wife.html Diamond Mountain retreat death: Ian Thorson dies after fleeing mysterious yoga retreat with wife | Mail Online][http://www.willcoxrangenews.com/news/article_9a724b6c-b4da-11e1-8c99-001a4bcf887a.html Case closed in death of former participant at Buddhist retreat - Arizona Range News: News]{{cite web |title=An Open Letter from Geshe Michael |date=April 26, 2012 |publisher=[[Diamond Mountain Center]] |first=Michael |last=Roach}} The incident received international attention in the news media, with a number of former students voicing criticisms of Roach. ==Bibliography== *''The Diamond Cutter: The Buddha on Managing Your Business and Your Life'', Three Leaves, 2000. ISBN 0-385-49791-1 *''The Essential Yoga Sutra: Ancient Wisdom for Your Yoga'', with Christie McNally, Three Leaves, 2005. ISBN 0-385-51536-7 *''The Garden: A Parable'', Image, 2000. ISBN 0-385-49789-X *''How Yoga Works: Healing Yourself and Others With The Yoga Sutra'', with Christie McNally. Diamond Cutter Press, 2005. ISBN 0-9765469-0-6 *''The Tibetan Book of Yoga: Ancient Buddhist Teachings on the Philosophy and Practice of Yoga'', [[Doubleday (publisher)|Doubleday]], 2004.
